text: This Problem gives students the opportunity to practice the scaling strategies they explored earlier. They choose part-to-part or part-to-whole ratios, as appropriate. The scaling strategies solve proportions, foreshadowing the next Problem, where proportions are defined and solving proportions is dealt with directly.
Note: This Problem is a review of Comparing Quantities, except for the new format of writing ratios in fraction form. Be sure to emphasize the difference between a ratio (2:3) and a fraction (2/3).

Implementation Note: You may want to use Teaching Aid 1.2: Ratio Type Notation and Learning Aid 1.2A: Recipes to introduce the Problem and have students work on the Initial Challenge. The What If section shows strategies and solutions to the Initial Challenge. Keeping students’ books closed (or only viewing the Initial Challenge) by using the learning aids will allow students to do the Initial Challenge without influence from the What If.
Explore ratios with a focus on finding and using equivalent ratios to solve problems.

• equivalent ratios written in fraction form
  • equivalent ratios are related by a common multiplicative factor
  • equivalent ratios can be found by “scaling ratios”: scaling-up (multiplying) a given ratio or scaling-down (dividing) from the given ratio
  • using ratio relationships to solve problems is referred to as reasoning with ratios and can be a quick and powerful tool for problem solving
Explore connections between ratio table, equivalent ratios, scaling, and an equation.
